item.title: Hong Kong Police Detain 9 After Finding Materials for Explosives
item.description: The discovery comes a few days before the city’s legislature is set to vote on changes to how the city will select its next leader.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Police officers at a vacant television studio where explosives were found on Monday in the Sai Kung area of the city’s New Territories.

item.title: E.U. Urged to Plan for Greece to Default
item.description: Officials from Germany were among the most outspoken voices, with one warning of the need for a “state of emergency” to handle a potential fallout.
item.dc:creator: JAMES KANTER, ALISON SMALE and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Jens Weidmann, the president of the Bundesbank, Germany’s central bank, in Dresden last month. He warned of the danger that Greece would declare bankruptcy.

item.title: Letter From Europe: Horrors of Eritrea Met With a Shrug
item.description: While thousands of Eritrean migrants attempt the journey to Europe each month, an Eritrean journalist in Paris asks them to stay home and make a difference.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Dunhuang Journal: Plan for Tourist Attraction at Mogao Caves Worries Chinese Scholars
item.description: The effort to restore and protect the statues, figurines and frescoes of Buddha in Dunhuang has come against its toughest threat yet: tourists.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: An unrestored section of the Mogao Caves, a centuries-old time capsule of art along the Silk Road in Dunhuang, China, that holds some of the world’s greatest Buddhist treasures.

item.title: Modi’s Yoga Drive Takes Aim at Bad Habits and Bellies of India’s Capital
item.description: Yoga Day, the latest initiative introduced by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has proved to be a cultural challenge in New Delhi, a capital diagnosed by some has having a “Western lifestyle.”
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Government employees participating in a yoga class recently at the Morarji Desai National Institute of Yoga in Delhi.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Holden Chow on China, Elections and Hong Kong’s Attitude
item.description: Mr. Chow, of the pro-Beijing Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong, said it would be a mistake to vote against a proposal to allow all those eligible to cast a ballot in the 2017 election for the city’s top leader.
item.category: Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Holden Chow, vice chairman of the Democratic Alliance for the Betterment and Progress of Hong Kong.

item.title: Vatican Sets Trial for Ex-Ambassador Accused of Sexual Abuse
item.description: The Vatican said that in July it would open a trial of its former envoy to the Dominican Republic on charges of sexually abusing boys and of possessing child pornography.
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:description: Jozef Wesolowski, a former archbishop, was recalled from the Dominican Republic.

item.title: China Ends Recovery Efforts on Ship That Capsized on Yangtze
item.description: Officials said that the vessel had 454 people on board at the time of the accident on June 1, not 456 or 458, and that there were 12, not 14, survivors.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: The Oriental Star on Thursday as it was towed to a safer location after capsizing early this month on the Yangtze River in China.

item.title: U.N. Leader Calls Yemen a ‘Ticking Bomb,’ Amid Delay in Cease-Fire Talks
item.description: Negotiations had been due to start Sunday but were held up when the Houthi delegation initially refused to board the aircraft that was supposed to bring it to Geneva.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: The United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, during a news conference in Geneva on Monday.

item.title: Omar al-Bashir of Sudan Leaves South Africa, Avoiding Arrest
item.description: His private jet was seen flying out of a South African military airport near Pretoria, apparently unhindered by the authorities.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Omar al-Bashir of Sudan, center, posed for a group picture on Sunday at the African Union summit meeting in Sandton, South Africa.

item.title: Britons, Some Raising a Pint, Celebrate Magna Carta’s 800th Anniversary
item.description: Commemorations of the document that inspired protections for civil liberties include a ceremony with the queen, seminars, a musical and plans for a national beer day.
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: From left: Justin Welby, the archbishop of Canterbury; Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain; Queen Elizabeth II; and Prince Philip attended a ceremony for the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta in Runnymede, England, on Monday.

item.title: North Korean Soldier Braves DMZ to Defect to South
item.description: The teenage soldier was being debriefed after he arrived at a guard post in the South Korean half of the Demilitarized Zone, the Defense Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Zhang Weiwei on Why China Will Succeed Under the Communist Party
item.description: Mr. Zhang, a leading theorist of the “China model” of political and economic development, holds that China is on the right path and is destined to accomplish its goals.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Zhang Weiwei directs the Center for China Development Model Research at Fudan University.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Living Largely Off the Grid in China
item.description: On Lao Mountain, in coastal Shandong Province, a young couple have been conducting an experiment in self-sufficiency.
item.dc:creator: ADAM WU
item.media:description: Tang Guanhua inside the hut he spent more than two years constructing from bamboo, rocks and clay.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Soil Contamination Found Near Huge Mine in Western China
item.description: Greenpeace East Asia said that soil near a zinc and lead mine and smelting plant in Yunnan Province was unsafe for growing food.
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN
item.media:description: An aerial view of Asia’s largest zinc and lead mine, in Jinding, Yunnan Province.

item.title: Thousands Flee Syria as Kurds Gain on ISIS
item.description: Refugees who had been gathering on the Syrian side of the border with Turkey broke through the crossing, passing babies and their belongings through a barbed-wire fence.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: The Trans-Pacific Partnership and a President’s Legacy
item.description: The 12-nation deal President Obama has been negotiating in Asia could be imperiled, not by uncertainty abroad, but by challenges at home trying to convince Democrats of the deal’s importance.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: U.S. Airstrike in Libya Targets Planner of 2013 Algeria Attack
item.description: Libyan officials said the strike killed Mokhtar Belmokhtar, a former Al Qaeda leader and the mastermind of a 2013 terrorist seizure of an Algerian gas plant that left 38 foreign hostages dead.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An undated image of Mokhtar Belmokhtar, an Algerian militant leader reported to have been killed in an American airstrike.

item.title: Philae Spacecraft Reawakens on a Speeding Comet With Data for Scientists
item.description: In November, the European Space Agency landed a probe on a speeding comet, but it lost battery power after 60 hours. The spacecraft began transmitting data packets to earth on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS ST. FLEUR

item.title: Bid by Omar al-Bashir of Sudan to Avoid Arrest Is Tested in South Africa
item.description: A South African court issued an interim order to prevent the Sudanese president from leaving the country after the International Criminal Court sought his arrest on genocide charges.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan at the opening session of an African Union meeting in Johannesburg on Sunday.
